content.body: why is `WeakRef.prototype.constructor` normative optional? https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-weak-ref.prototype.constructor
SES IIRC?
how so? I could see WeakRef itself being normative optional, but what is the point of shipping a WeakRef whose prototype does not have a `constructor` property?
content.formatted_body: how so? I could see WeakRef itself being normative optional, but what is the point of shipping a WeakRef whose prototype does not have a constructor property?

content.body: and I don't see discussion at https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2089 other than "we're adding inline normative optional spec text" from yulia in the PR description without further explanation
content.formatted_body: and I don't see discussion at https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/2089 other than "we're adding inline normative optional spec text" from yulia in the PR description without further explanation

content.body: The motivation is that it can be removed so you wouldn't be able to create a new WeakRef from an instance. Aka sharing an instance to observe the liveness of one object doesn't allow you start observing the liveness of any object.
but why would an implementation ship that rather than requiring code to delete the property?
it seems bizarrely special-cased from an implementation perspective
same reason an implementation would "ship" without any other normative-optional thing
The idea is that an environment without access to the contructor through the prototype would still be a compliant JavaScript environment. Aka not introduce code that expects it to be there.

code that requires normative-optional things to exist isn't portable; it's reasonable for an implementation to only support portable code (where "implementation" could include "any environment that's been prepared with first-run JS code")

* code that requires normative-optional things to exist isn't portable; it's reasonable for an implementation to only support portable code (where "implementation" could include "any environment that's been prepared with first-run JS code")

m.new_content.body: code that requires normative-optional things to exist isn't portable; it's reasonable for an implementation to only support portable code (where "implementation" could include "any environment that's been prepared with first-run JS code")

content.body: Richard Gibson  Is there any reason you would want it to always be there?
content.formatted_body: Richard Gibson Is there any reason you would want it to always be there?

content.body: besides the "it's different
to avoid the cognitive burden of an exception to the rule that every built-in constructor's prototype has a `constructor` property referencing it
content.formatted_body: to avoid the cognitive burden of an exception to the rule that every built-in constructor's prototype has a constructor property referencing it

content.body: `delete builtInConstructor.prototype.constructor` is always allowed, but only in this one case is a conforming implementation allowed to ship without the property present at all
content.formatted_body: delete builtInConstructor.prototype.constructor is always allowed, but only in this one case is a conforming implementation allowed to ship without the property present at all

content.body: Do you have a specific use case, or is it conceptual only ?
the latter
it's not even like it allows SES or similar to avoid the `delete WeakRef.prototype.constructor` code, because conforming implementations can and do ship with it
content.formatted_body: it's not even like it allows SES or similar to avoid the delete WeakRef.prototype.constructor code, because conforming implementations can and do ship with it

content.body: No but it means the environment SES/lockdown creates is still a fully compliant JavaScript environment
no, that isn't true because of the other mutations
Function.prototype, Date.now, Math.random, etc.

Ok, fair, it's one less difference, and we're working on mitigating the others. E.g. all those you mention are there, but they throw. Doing that on `Function.prototype` is ok because SES has to virtualize `Function` anyway.
content.formatted_body: Ok, fair, it's one less difference, and we're working on mitigating the others. E.g. all those you mention are there, but they throw. Doing that on Function.prototype is ok because SES has to virtualize Function anyway.

content.body: an implementation that shipped with a https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-math.random that throws exceptions would not be conforming with https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-math.random
Having the spec say "this may not be there" encourages programs to not rely on it being there.
SES lockdown intentionally restricts the environment in ways that violate the spec; why should there be a special exception for WeakRef.prototype.constructor?

Right, I think we're trying to compare something that was there from the beginning, and something that is introduced more recently. E.g. for arrays, most original methods seem to skip over holes, but all newer ones don't. It's a difference that avoids repeating previous mistakes in light of new knowledge
if that were the case, then shipping it should be considered a violation. This allows for differences that are rightfully discouraged elsewhere
we don't permit implementations to pass holes to Array.prototype.flatMap callbacks
so I guess I have my answer about why the annotation is there, but the answer doesn't make sense
